poem:
Matcha Mornings

In London, Anja sips
the green enchantment,
a whisked morning ritual
from a far-off place

where tea bowls are cradled
like small, mossy stones.
Now, the struggle to find
green's glow is gone,

its steam rising
in familiar fog,
her heart a temple
to faraway leaves.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The new green giant: how matcha took over the world Anja Opie, a marketing manager in London, is a self-proclaimed matcha superfan. “I used to live in Japan and it was there I fell in love with it,” she says. She hasn’t always been able to find the vibrant green tea back in the UK. Five years ago, it was a struggle, but now she has matcha three times a week “without fail”. From elusive". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
